Academic Integrity in the Online Environment

Assessing students in the online environment comes with a lot of questions for both teachers and students alike. Before we take a deeper look into all the ways digital forms of assessment can be beneficial, it’s important to address a common concern: what does academic integrity mean and what do violations of academic integrity look like online?

Directions: Select each word below to review and understand how Michigan Virtual defines academic integrity and its violations in an online environment.

Academic Integrity

All work you submit is created by you and is an original representation of your work. It means that what you submit is your own work.

Plagiarism

When a student who represents work that has been copied from any published resource such as, but not limited to, Wikipedia, electronic texts, videos, or any source without the proper credit (any resource that is not a student’s own work).
Examples:
Common sources include Wikipedia, Chegg, Brainly, Course Hero

  • Student copies a paragraph of text directly from Wikipedia as their own
  • Student searches and finds an entire essay on Course Hero and submits
  • Student finds assignment on Chegg and changes a few words before submitting

-Boleski and Trombetta, Feb. 2022

Cheating

When a student represents any other person’s work from any source including hard drives, software, or answer banks (such as, but not limited to, Yahoo! Answers, Craigslist, translator services, etc.) as their own. An example of cheating includes inappropriate email soliciting answers, documented inappropriate discussions, student-to-student cheating, and cheating in a lab classroom.
Examples:

  • Student uses Google Translate to do their Spanish assignment
  • Student uses Photomath to solve the problems on an Algebra test
  • Students work together (against class policy) and turn in a duplicate assignment

-Boleski and Trombetta, Feb. 2022

Student Academic Broker

A student who posts work to a secondary source, such as, but not limited to, Facebook, Yahoo! Answers, Google Docs, or shares virtual or hard copy file of any work whether or not compensation occurs.
Examples:

  • Student shares their lab report to Course Hero for others to access
  • Student who took the online course last semester shares work with a student who is taking the online course this semester
  • Student shares assignment with another student to show them what they’re supposed to be doing

-Boleski and Trombetta, Feb. 2022

Remember:

No matter the assessment type or tool used in a classroom, it’s important for teachers to have a clear understanding of what academic integrity looks like in their context; in the same way, it is equally important for teachers to establish and share these expectations with their students each year. If you are interested in viewing all of the policies that Michigan Virtual shares with students, you may explore them on the Policies page.
